One possibility is using assertions within your code, not the test. It all
depends on what the code actually does. If you can find a deterministic way
to check (inside the loop) that the loop itself has been going on for "too
long", or that it didn't meet an expected boundary condition, then you can
just assert against that. The next JDK will support assertions, but I wrote
my own simple assertion classes. If an assertion fails, it throws a
RuntimeException. Then you can just check for that exception within your
unit test.

Of course, asserting continuously might slow down your loop. Also, some
might argue against "polluting the code with the tests", but I don't really
care about that - I use assertions everywhere, both as a "permanent test" in
production code and to better communicate my intentions.
